intro: Astragalus rusbyi var. longissimus, commonly known as the long-stemmed milkvetch, is a perennial forb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, pea-like flowers that range in color from white to pale pink. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats such as sagebrush steppe and grasslands. It has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. This species is of interest to botanists and ecologists due to its adaptability to arid environments.
